cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

EXPRESS MAIL STEAMERS
FROM
ALEXANDRIA, PORT SAID, AND SUEZ,
TO
NAPLES, MARSEILLES,
GENOA, SOUTHAMPTON, ANTWERP,
BREMEN, HAMBURG, AMERICA,
EASTERN ASIA, AUSTRALIA Etc.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. "Oruba" will leave Suez about October 5
R.M.S "Ophir" will leave Suez about October 19.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Port Said October 23
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said October 8
Passengers returning by the Line obtain one-third rebate off the above fares if leaving England before the end of October.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all particulars apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-906

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES MAY TO OCTOBER.
Port Said to Tilbury £ 12.15.0. and Port Said to Marseilles £ 9.0.0.
Passengers returning by the Line will be granted a rebate of 33% off the full fare i.e. Liverpool to Port Said £ 11.6.8. and Marseilles to Port Said £ 8.0.0.
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, RANGOON. Departure from Suez.
S.S. Herefordshire 7182 tons, Oct. 11.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Cheshire 5,775 tons, October 1.
Agents– Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO's LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 23 for London.
S.S. BURMA 5600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 6 for London.
S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 20 for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d'Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d'un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d'un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5 and 19 December.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 8 and 22 October, 5 and 19 November, 3, 17 and 31 December.
Syrian-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 1, 15 and 29 October, 12 and 26 November, 10 and 24 December.
Far East Lines.

To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service about 8 October, 8 Nov., 8 Dec.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about 19 Oct, 3, 19 Nov., 19 Dec 4 p.m.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 Nov., 1 Dec (Winter Line).
East African Line.
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa-Bay, and Durban about 3 Oct., 2 Nov., 3 Dec..

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: HOTEL BRISTOL. CAIRO.
div.p: Full South, Electric Light, opposite Esbekieh Gardens, Large Verandahs, Moderate Charges,
CHAS. BAUER, Proprietor.

The Hotel is beautifully fitted up and is in the most central part of Cairo. Terms for pension fare at the rate of ten shillings a day. Special terms for officers of Army of Occupation. 24,882-31-10-5

div.head: NEW VICTORIA HOTEL,
div.p: Open all the year round.
San Stefano, Near Alexandria, Halt No. 2.

Specially built in 1904 for a class Hotel with every modern comfort. Magnificent Dining room, Saloons, Smoking room, largo Verandahs and Garden. Electric light. MODERATE CHARGES. Ten minutes by carriage or Palais tram from Sidi Gaber.—Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation. C. F. RAISIG. Manager.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The northernly breeze continues and the barometer is rising.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1906..

div.head: "TWO'S COMPANY."
div.p: The reception accorded in France to the latest expression of German diplomacy has been marked both by singular unanimity of opinion and by a remarkably clear perception of the real purport and intention of the manifesto. Neither perplexity nor apprehension his any place in the mental attitude with - which the ingénions article in the "Deutsche Revue" is discussed by Parisian newspapers of widely-differing shades of political opinion. It is perfectly well seen that, for good reasons of her own, Germany would greatly like to add a fifth wheel to the Anglo-French coach ; and there is little hesitation visible in the response of French opinion that the vehicle goes capitally in its present condition, while the possible risks and inconveniences of the new style of locomotion would be both obvions and gratuitous. One point emerges in particular from this collective opinion of the nation as expressed in the Paris newspapers, and that is the almost irreconcilable barrier to any community of feeling between France and Germany which is imposed by the two lost provinces. "We see your outstretched hand," says the "Liberté," "but it is empty. Now, if it is only for sentimental reasons—merci bien!" There are, indeed, as the "Globe" says, incidents of much more recent date than the spoliation of 1871 which inevitably present themselves to the mind of France when the Germans begin to talk of friendship.

div.head: BRITISH TRADE WITH AFRICA.
div.p: The current issue of "The Board of Trade Journal" giver a very useful abstract of the business carried on between the United Kingdom the African Continent for the last five years, and the following summary of results shows in what directions our trade has mainly grown in that period : -

The imports into the United Kingdom from Africa have increased from £26,435,000 to £32,684,000 – a gain of 23 ½ per cent.—and the exports from the United Kingdom to Africa have advanced from £32,431,000 to £35,649,000—a rise of 9 ¾ per cent. The expansion of our trade with oar own possessions is hardly as satisfactory as it might be and is less so when it is realised that but for an increase of £2,000,000 in the export of dia- monds from the Cape, the total would show a considerable decline. The bést all round exhibit is that made by the Egyptian section of our commerce. The large advance in oar dealings with Portuguese Africa is explained by the transit trade through Dalagoa Bay. Our staple export to Africa is cotton goods! which constitute a fifth of the aggregate outward shipments.
An understanding having/been come to between the commissioners for the delimitation of the Turco-Egyptian frontier, the solution of the question is impending. (Havar)
The murderess of General Minn was hanged at Schlusselburg prison yesterday. The trial of revolutionaries by drum head courts martial is beginning to take pines throughout Russia ( Feuter).
Amongst those arrested are 600 Jews. (H.)
The Navy, War, and State Departments are actively engaged in making preparations in connection with the Cuban outbreak, although the intention of intervention is disclaimed. (Reuter)

div.head:
CHINESE CUSTOMS.
SIR R. HART'S PPOSITION.

div.p: The President of the Association of the Chambers of Commerce of Bristol read a letter from Sir E. Grey stating that Sir Robert Hart had been twice verbally instructed by the Chinese authorities to continue the administration of the Customs. (Reuter)

While the assurances given by China that Sir Robert Hart's position will not be affected mast be accepted, the program of events art bring closely watched. It is not intended to allow any breach of obligations on the part of China with reference to this matter. (R).
The insurgent chief abandoned Mogador on the 8th instant. The reason for his sudden departure is unknown. (Reuter)

div.head:
AUSTRALIA AND BETTING.
STRINGENT BILL INTRODUCED.

div.p: A stringent Anti-Betting Bill has been introduced. It suppresses charity raffles and private card playing. It prohibits sweepstakes above 5s., and punishes the publication of betting news. (Reuter)
Count Goluchowsky and the French and Turkish Ambassadors have visited the Khedive. (Feuter)

div.head:
DUKE OF CONNAUGHT.
MADE GERMAN FEILD MARSHAL.

div.p: The Duke of Connaught has been appointed a German Field Marshal. (Reuter)

It is understood that owing to the serious growth of sleeping sickness in Uganda the Liverpool School of Medicine has send out an expedition to investigate the malady. Another will go to West Africa to endeavour to trace the cause of black-water fever. (Reuter)

The Princess Royal has been unwell for some time as the result of an attack of influenza. An operation has been performed and satisfactory progress continues to be made. No bulletins are issued. (Reuter)
All preparations have been made to re-float the S.S. Manchuria. Every hope has be fulfilled so far. (Reuter)
St. Leger Stakes. - 1. Troutbeck, 2. Prince William, 3. Beppo. (Reuter)
Cattle Plague
Daring the week ended the 9th inst., nine cases of cattle plagne occurred in Egypt.
Slaves Freed.
Daring last month the Slave Trade Repres sion Department granted manomission papers to five Sudanese, one male and four female.
The Plague.
A fatal case of plague at Alexandria is announced to-day. The victim was a native living at Kom el-Shoogafah, and he died out of hospital.
Court Irregularities.
Two clerks of the Ezbekieh Court have been arrested and interrogated, as the result of irregularities having been discovered in the court registers.
Veterinary School
To accommodate the growing number of papile, it has been decided to enlarge the Veterinary School. The autumn. term opens on October 1, and admission will cease on the 25th inst.
The Jacobin Club.
The new formation of a Nationalist Liberal Native Club in Cairo has been mooted. Fehmy Abou Saada Bey, of Cairo, has been sent a subscription of £10 for founding this new political club.
Alexandria Couvernorat
The Ministry of the Interior has appointed Ismail Eff. Nazim, Moswin in the Alexandria Governorat, in place of Osman Eff. Rifki, who was transferred recently to another post under the same Ministry.
The Census.

The date on which the census of the popula tion of Egypt will be taken bas not been fixed, bat it is believed that steps are being taken to get the operation through in less than three hours on the day chosen.
The Shoubra Crime.

Forther evidence in the Shoubra crime is daily forthcoming, but it does not add to what is already known, nor weaken the charge preferre 1. The judge will shortly embody the depositions and counter evidence.
Useful Innovation.

A barrier is to be bailt between Shoubra Bridge and the new buildings separating the central station from that of Port Limoun, and it is to have two gateways. This barrier is to ward off tramps and pickpockets.
Tantah Agricultural Show.

The Tantah Municipal Commission has decided to defray all the expenses in connection with the reception of H.H. the Khedive, who will open the agricultural show there next month. An Alexandrian hotel has been en- trusted with the banquet that is to be held.
C.P.O. for Cairo:

The rumour has again been revived that the General Post Office is to be removed from Alexandria to Cairo. Although no definite decision has been come to on the subject, we understand that it is highly probable that, in the not very distant future, the Postal Administration will finally be located in the Capital.
Man Electrocuted.

At Abbassieb, on Tuesday night, a tramway electric wire snapped. The conductor of a car which was passing at the time, named Youssef El Chami, thought that the pole of the car had left the wire and mounted on top to replace it. In the dark he accidentally took hold of the wire and met his death, being electrocuted on the spot.
Salaries Commission.

Lord Edward Cecil's commission has asked that lists of petty employés in various administrations which have not yet been included in the general reform, be sent immediately, and the first to reply was the Upper Egypt Irrigation Department. At Monday's meeting the status of officials receiving between ten and twenty pounds a month was discussed. Those receiving more than this will be considered next year.
Jane Hading in Cairo.

M. Alsime Leblanc has applied to the Ministry of Public Works for an authorisation to give seven performances at the Khedivial Opera House with Mme Jane Hading between the 16th and 24th November. The plays will include Sapho, Le Maitre de Forges, La Rajale, La Petite Marquise, La Chatelaine, Le Retour de Jérusalem et le Demi-Monde. As the theatrical season only begins on the 25th November permission will no doubt be granted.
Circassian's Exit.

A Circassian Bey of very hand some appearance, and standing over six feet, who had boughts pitticket for the amateur theatricals at San Stefano yesterday,thought he would prefer a private box for himself and his friends at the same price. He was, however, soon apprised of his error, but refused either to make good the difference, or vacate, but eat with an immovable cast of countenance that would have made quite a lay figure on the stage alongside of Chinese and Japanese dolls. He soon found himself the cynosure of all eyes, and to the relief of all he was gradually stared out of the theatre.
The Progress of Egypt.

The Progress of Egypt manifests itself not only in the material domain, but also in the intellectual one. The Berlitz Schools, for example, have seen the number of their teachers and pupils more than tripled since the estab lishment of these schools. It is true that this is due also to the admirable system that is employed there, and to the choice of teachers. Anyone can assure himse'f of these advantages by a free trial lesson in English, French, Italian, German, Arabic, Greek, etc. [ADVT.].

div.head: THE SULTAN'S HEALTH.
div.p: SECRECY AT YILDIZ
CONSTANTINOPLE, September 12.
Drs. Bergmann and Bier hava arrived. At the Palace the utmost secrecy is observed as to the Sultan's state of health.
Havas)
The Constantinople correspondent of the "Petit Parisien" states that the Sultan's malady is making rapid progress, and his great feebleness was evident to everyone at his Accession reception.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE BANK.
div.p: The negotiations between the Egyptian Government and the National Bank of Egypt for the conversion of the latter into a State institution have been completed. Besides retaining its concession of note-issue the Bauk will benceforth be the depository of the Treasary balances, as also of the fands appertaining to the Mixed Tribunals; it will pay the pensions on account of the State and practically transact all the Government bosiness. The expansion of the sphere of influence of the bank is a matter for congratulation for the shareholders and British interests.

div.head: THE LATE PRINCE IBRAHIM.
div.p: It is said that the mother of the late Prince Mohamed Ibrahim has give Aly Bey Sadik power of attorney in order to secure her share of the deceased estate, which, it is expected will be placed under the supervision of the Khedivial Maieb. The late Prince used to make his mother on allowonce of L.E. 30 a month.

div.head: PRINCESS ROUSKIAH
div.p: Princess Rouskiah, whose sudden death we announced two days ago, was the daughter of Mustapha Pasha Fazel, brother to the late Khedive I mail. She was the sister of Princess Nazly Fazel and Princess Zahra Hanem. Her body will be brought to Cairo for interment in the vaults of the Khedivial Family.

div.head: LEILET-UL-MIRAG.
div.p: To-morrow evening, the Wakfs Administration will celebrate the religious fel. "Leilet-ul-Mirag" at the Citadel Mosque, Cairo. H.H. Prince Mohamed Aly will attend the ceremony as representing the Khedive.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: THE 'POUPÉES ANIMÉES."

We have seen this show elsewhere, and produced by professionals, but for mechanical movement and beautiful apparel, no less than arhusing effect, Prof. Longhi's dainty little amateurs who appeared on the boards at the New Theatre, San Stefano, yesterday afternoon proved themselves quite as good as full-blown artistes. The costumes alone must have cost a large sum, for they were of the most exquisite workaanship. The staging, also, added a final touch of colouring to an already animated scene; the decorations were the handiwork of Mr. Rovescalli of Milan, who had wonderfully transformed bare walls into a German toy shop. The show was announced by Miss Olga Lusena, a wee mite in white, who in a witty and well delivered prologue, assured the amused audience that they were "real" artistes. The ballet pantomime was in twb acts, and there were "real live" dramatis petsore and inanimate ' dolls," namely "Real Live Parsons" :-Mr. Pierre Zabar, Lord Palmerston; Mlle Nelly Kremer, Lady Palmersten; Mlle Lucy Salams, Miss Lily, Mile Jeannette Landauer, Miss Ketty, Mlle Linda Fanare, Miss Violet, Mlle Marthe Ciribelli, Miss Fanny, their daughters; Messrs. Ottavio Patracchi, and René Landauer, the Homergatte brothers; Mr. Georges Pardo, a peasant; Mlle Alda Fanaro, his wife; Mlle Olga Fanaro, ndree. Dolls: Mr. Félix Salams, Chinaman; Mile Ladie Cordachi, Tyrolese; Mlle Olga Lasens, Baby; Mile Georgette Salama, Chinese lady; Mile Rachel Salama, Spaniab lady; Mlle Willca Vivante, Geisha; I équie Toriel, Jockey; Mile Wanda Vivante, Fairy; Mle Hélène Ayraut, Pink Doll; Mile Marie Ayraut, Blue Doll; Mile Marcelle Salama, Red Doll; Mlle Edith Riches, Yellow Doll; Mr. Joseph Cordechi, Musketeer; Mlle Marie Harz, Loais XIII. lady; Mile Marie Salama, Vivandière; Mile Rané Fanaro, Torero; Mile Choukri Hory, Pierrot; Mlle Rosette Hiri, Pierrette.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman 8. S. City of Oxford sailed from Malta last night and is due bere on Sonday morning with passengers and general cargo.

div.head: PAUVRE FILLE.
div.p: Suivant le "Journal da Caire," are jeare femme de chambre française, rendue mère par on barbarin, aurait été refasée à l'hôpital fran- çris da Caire, où elle s'était présentée pour accoucher à l'insn de ses parente. Henreuse- ment l'hôpital italien a montré plus d'hams- Dité et accueilli avec bienveillance la panvre fille. Nous voulons croire, aveo le "Journal dn Caire, que le refus de l'Hôtel Dien (hôpital trar çais) est imputable à la méprice d'on employé subalterne; autrement il serait inqualifiable.

div.head: THE DENISHWAI AFFAIR.
div.p: FURTHER OFFICIAL PAPERS
THE MURDERERS' FEEBLE DEFENCE
Farther papers respecting the attack on British officers at Denishwai have been issued.

The Acting Judicial Adviser to the Egyptian Government forwards a translation of the indictment and procès verbaur of the preliminary inquiry in the case of the medical evidence and of the procès verbal d'audience. Mr. Findlay, in transmitting these to Sir Edward Grey, calls attention to the feeble character of the speeches for the defence. "The three advocates in question are," he says, "among the ablest members of the Egyptian Bar, and two of them had volunteered their services. That they could find nothing more to say in defence of their clients is the best proof that their claim was indefensible. A study of these documents will show that the proceedings were conducted in a perfectly regalar and methodical manner, and that no pains were spared to arrive at the truth. There is no sign of undue haste, still less of panic or vindictiveness.

"Mohammed Bey Youssef," he continues, "who defended, expressed his sorrow that such an act should have been committed against the army of occupation, which had osused the unanimous indignation of all Egyptians. What lessened its gravity was that it happened in a poor village, and was caused by ignorant people. He rejected the theory that the pigeons were the cause, sud said the reasons were the fire and wounds inflicted on the natives, which led the owner of the thresh- ing floor to seize the officer whom he thought to be the cause. It was difficult to believe that the accused had the intention to murder, as they carried no weapons."

div.head: MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL.
div.p: The return of Mastapha Pasha Kamel to his native land is to be rignalized by a banquet. Subscriptions will be received by Maitre Mohamed Bey Farid, of Cairo. It will be worth while observing whether the Egyptians will show as much enthusiasm for the Kamel banquet as they did for the recent Accession fêtes. When it is remembered that the grand total of the subscriptions for the whole of Egypt to the Sultan Accession fête celebration only amounted to L.E. 396, the subscriptions for the banquet should amount to the mean between the positions which the Caliph of Islam and the Egyptian Patriot respectively occapy in the hearts of the Egyptian people. The comparison of the two totals will be in- teresting.

The idea of the banquet has not been received with universal favour, and the other Nationalist newspapers are rather sore at the honour which is to be shown to Kamel. "Al Moayad" and "Al Minbar" declare that such a demonstration is quite ancalled-for, as the Egyptians have entered on a political struggle with the most powerful nation in the world, and such trampery self-advertisement is on- worthy of the sacred cause of Egyptian Nationalism.
A special feature of the banquet will be its purely "national" character for nothing but Egyptian drinks and dishes will be partaken of, all European wines and oaisine being rigorously eschewed.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: It had been reported that the Princess Sheveikiar, sister of the late Prince Mohamed Bay Ibrahim, bas developed a cardiac affection in consequence of the tragic death of her brother. We are authorised to state, however, that the Princess is not suffering from any heart attack.
Adly Pasha Yaghen, President of the Wakfs, is expected to return from Barope on the 4th proxo.
Corbet Bey, Procureur Général, has returned to Cairo from Barope.
Jadge Hannah Nasrallah Bey retires next March on an annual pension of L.E. 1,200.
Mr. Amos, Judge of the Court of First Instance, has been named as his scccessor.

The death has just occurred of Mlle. A. Balengon, as a result of cerebral congestion. The deceased, who came to Egypt in 1865, remained for many years in Helmich Palace as governess to H.H. the Khedivah-Mother and her sisters, the Princesses Zeinab and Tewfida. Mlle Balengon was an aont of M. R. Fourtan, member of the Egyptian Institute.
Osman Bey Bamat, Inspector in the Ministry of the Interior, who was acting Sab-Madir of Ismailia, has returned to Cairo.
Mr. Adamson leaves to-day for Rasheid to inspect the mines there. He returns to-morrow evening.

The marriage arranged between Captain Cecil Grimshaw, DS.O., 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, and Violet, youngest dangter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Alderson, of Ramleb, will take place at St. Mary Abbot's Church, Kensington, on Wednesday, the 3rd of October, at half-past two o'clock.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions exprossed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit -within certain necessary limits - free discussion,

div.head: THE SANITARY ADMINISTRATION.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, We have the honour to inform you that we have been through the article inserted in the number 7592 of your periodical dated the 7th September under the heading "Extraordinary Statements, Complaints in England against the Sanitary Administration." The purport of the statement inserted by the "Chemist and Droggist" has been given to the above periodical by, we daresay, an unreliable source of information, and it is quite necessary to point out here all the real circumstances of the fact. It is to be borne in mind, that the new Egyptian Law for Pharmacies enacted that no one can deal with the pharmacist work without holding a special diploma for that purpose. The consequence of such a measure in & country where many people are dealing from long and long time with the pharmacist work, was that their livelihood should be broken owing to the fast that such people are unable to comply with the exigencies of the new Law. A transitory measure was then necessary in order to save them from the bad condition in which they should have been thrown in virtually by the above law. Indeed a proposal has been made to the Sanitary Administration by the Qualified Pharmacist Committee to the effect that all the persons who are working in the various pharmacies of the town from several years and have got a certain experience in such a special work without having a diploma, would be examined in order to be granted, if they are successful, with a certificate of Assistant Pharmacist. Certainly for such an exam, a curriculum of Pharmacy should have beea established for this parpose, but the Sanitary Administration has not prepared any programme for such a carricalam, because it has not yet officially approved the proposal of the Pharmacists Committee. The "Mokattam" in one of its last numbers having stated that very likely an examination for us will be held next December, we have been compelled to be taught with some elementary principles of the pharmacist science from an experienced and well-qualified man. We have selected for this purpose M. Bahari, who after having been authorised by his chiefs on sobount of his being a Government official, is giving us lectores in his private laboratory from nearly a month. We may add that the lessons given to us by Mr. Bahari are based on a programme prepared by the Pharmacists Committee and not by the Sanitary Administration, as this Department has not yet officiallly approved the application of the aforesaid committee as said above. As for the fees paid to M. Bahari they are the following: P.T. 250 per month for those among us who are owners of pharmacies, and their number does not exceed four.
P.T. 80 to 150 per month paid by 20 stadents, each proportionately to his monthly salary.

Lectures free of charge are given to those who have a monthly salary not exceeding £5, although they have offered to Mr. Bahari a monthly fee of P.T. 50 each, and Mr. Bahari' refused it entirely. The number of these persons does not exceed ten.

The lectures are given twice a week from 10.30 p.m. to 12.30 a.m. and as there are no special books for such lectures, ('he book "L'Assistant du Pharmacien" by Prof. O. Dinkler should be on sale by the Library Diemer not before next October) Mr. Babari is writing always the lecture be is giving to us, and a copy of it is by him delivered to us as well. Each lecture requires & preparation for at least one hour, and two hours for its writing, so five hours are required for each. The total of the weekly hours employed by Mr. Babari atteins at least 10; so it makes 40 houre during the month, which is very far from being eight hours only as stated by the "Chemist and Druggist." As regards the statement of this periodical that those who joined these classes were sure of passing, we can say that such a statement is antrae; M. Bahari is always recommending as not to be absent from the lectures, adding that we must rely on our own work and zeal only.

Morever many persons come to the lectures at the beginning and they did not continue to attend; it would be at least strange that such persone, being sare to pass, will so discontinne their attendance. We are very grateful to Mr. Babari for the activity, zal and plain dealing he is displaying with us in giving his lectures, and we are unable to express him all the thanks he deserves for such purpose.
Many thanks for the kindly hospitality of your columns to the above letter and we have the honour to be, Sir, your obedient servants: Signed:-
div.byline: L Maroun, F. Boutarel,[Selim For waghi, Marc Angel, Kamel Agami, Habib Sadek, Georges Chahine, Joseph Samuel, Selim Alaouzi, Blie J. Constantaki, Anastase Jeanuser, Habib Abey, Constantine N. Coagnio, Pansyotti N. Kannadelice, F. Tadros, Os. Hassan, P. P. Aebker, R. Seleneoail, B. Aghohian, Ibrahim Rajab, K. Akksonf, Dimitri Faroun, Const. Dayoule, Wenis Kayal, Mikhail Boutros.

div.head: EGYPT AND PAN-ISLAMISM.
div.p: "EGYPT FOR THE EGYPTIANS."
Mustapha Pasha Kamel contributes the following article to the "Tempe:"

J'ai la l'article publié dans le Temps da 22 aût dernier sur le Panislamisme en Egypte". Son auteur & commis de grandes erreurs et n'a fait que répéter les attaques dirigées contre nous par les ennemis du réveil national égyptien.

Je ne cherche pas à savoir si ces erreurs sont voulues ou non; mais ces accusations, si contraires à la vérité et si blessantes pour notre patriotieme et notre dignité, ne peuvent pas me laisser indifférent. C'est pourquoi (je demande à l'impartialité bien connue du Temps de publier cette réponse.

Tout patriote, à quelque nationalité qu'il appartienne, ne peut sincèrement demander aux Egyptiens d'avoir da la reconnaissance pour la Grande Bretagne. L'amour de l'indé- pendance du sol natal est le plus beau, le plus noble des sentimente, celui sans lequel la vie serait bien misérable. Les Anglais ont occupé notre pays en "amis" et non pas en conquérants, et par tous les dieux ils ont juré de rendre l'Egypte aux Egyptiens. Au lieu de tenir leurs promesees, ils ont rendu le poids de l'occupation bien lourd et ont tout fait pour indisposer contre eux tout Egyptien.

Faire le procès de l'occupation britannique n'est pas le sujet de cette lettre. On connalt assez nos griefs contre le régime de lord Cromer. Mais je me plais à rappeler, en passant, que lord Dufferin a dit les Egyptiens auraient le droit de hair, & i de leurs cœears, l'Angleterre, malgré tout bien qu'elle puisse lear faire, si elle continusità occuper leur pays, car l'indépendance n'a pas de prix. M. Gladatone, lui aussi, m'a donné, dans les lettres qu'il m'a éorites en 1895 et 1896, pleinement raison. Nous ne faisons dono que suivre les indications de ces deux grands Anglais.

Il est aussi une autre vérité irréfutable. Pendant les trois premières années du règne da khédive Tewfik, de 1879 à 1882, l'Egypte a connu une toute autre vie que celle d'auparavant. Les tribunaux indigènes ont été créés, le code a été promulgaé, et l'Egypte a ea un moment son Parlement.

Or, c'est l'Angleterre qui a détrait oe Parlement en promettant à l'Egypte ane Constitation plus solide. Il y a maintenant vingt-quatre ans que nous attendons cette Constitution et que le pouvoir absola des anciens vice-rois d'Egypte est exercé par le représentant de la Grande Bretagne au Caire.
Avonez que ce n'est pas là un fait de natare à faire aimer l'Angleterre par les Egyptiens!

On a donné en Europe au mot "panislamisme" un sens qu'il ne peut pas avoir. Je répète ici ce que j'ai écrit au Figaro, an Lewa, et ce que j'ai dit partout qu'il n'y a pas un real musulman éclairé qui puisse croire une minute que les peuples de l'islam peavent se ligner contre l'Earope."

Si vraiment la Tarquie travaillait à unir tous les peuples musalmans autour d'elle pour faire la guerre à l'Europe et éloigner de toutes les contrées mabométanes les influences chrétiennes, comment se fait-il que l'Arabie, la sainte Arabie, soit si bouleversée par les révolutions et les luttes des insurgés arabes contre l'autorité turque ? Le panislamisme aurait dû incontestablement commencer par s'exercer là avant tout autre pays, la patrie du prophète devant être la première à marcher vera un pareil bat!

Et je me demande quel est l'homme, sain d'esprit, qui admettrait une minute que les peuples musulmans puissent vaincre toutes les puissances européennes. Et pourquoi le sultan garde t-il alors à son service et dans son gouvernement un nombre si grand de fonctionnaires chrétiens it fluents? Et. comment concilier ce prétendu fanatisme farouche avec l'amitié qui le lie à un empereur des plas chrétiens ?

La vérité, la pure vérité est que le panislanisme tel qu'il est compris en Barope n'existe point. Les musulmans, et les Toros en tête, ont compris depuis longtemps qu'aucune nation ne peut plus vivre isolée. Celle qui tenterait une pareille expérience serait simplement condamnée à mort.

Le sentiment qui existe réellement et sans conteste chez tous les peuples musulmans est. celui d'affection et de sympathie réciproques. Tout musulman désire, de toutes ses forces, voir ses coreligionnaires mieux traités, considé rés comme une partie vivante de l'humanité et respectés partout et par tous. Il souftre réellement toutes les fois que l'Europe intervient en Tarquie pour les chrétiens, rien que pour les chrétiens et au nom de l'humanité. Ses interventions prennent toujours la forme d'une action antimusulmane et nous déroutent.

La décadence des peuples musulmans a en les mêmes causes; lear relèvement doit avoir lien par les mêmes moyens. Ce n'est pas par ane chimérique coalition musulmane contre la chrétienté que ce relèvement peut devenir une réalité. C'est par l'instruction et la lumière. Et comme l'islam n'est pas seulement un dogme religieux, mais aussi une loi sociale, c'est en le montrant dans sa vérité, si défigurée pendant longtemps, qu'on peut réveiller les esprits et répandre la science.

La sympathie de tout musulman pour ses coreligionnaires est bien légitime, et ancan homme impartial ne peut la condamner. Sinon pourquoi trouve-t-on naturel que les chrétiens d'Earope s'intéressent tant an sort des chré- tiens d'Orient et les soutiennent souvent ? En ce qui concerne le prétenda fanatisme musulman en Egypte, j'affirme que plas d'an pays d'Europe connait le fanatisme intransigeant et hideax, alors que l'Egypte ne le connalt point. Nous n'avons ni antisémitisme, ni socialisme, ni anarohieme, ni tons oes partis qui se livrent une goerre sans meroi.

Nona sommes libéraux et toléranta par natare. Mais nous n'admettons pas qu'on toale aux pieds notre dignité et qu'on nous traite en inférieure. Nous voulons être les égaux des pins civilisés et nous nous révoltons contre l'idée que le dernier des étrangera qai dheart de faim dans son pays peut avoir dans le Lotre plas de droits que le plus grand d'entre nous.

A ceux qui aiment voir l'Egyptien courbé/et sans amour-propre, de faire lear denil et de crier, de par le monde, leur douleur de son réveil et de la conscience qu'il prend de soimême. Mais qu'ils ne disent pas que nous sommes fanatiques. C'est la plus fausse des accusations!

Où est-il, ce colon qui a trouvé les fellahs bien changés et qui veut quitter la campagne en Egypte 1 Qu'on me cite an seal com ! Tous ceux qui habitent l'Egypte sont unanimes à dire que le fellah eat l'être le plus dor x quand on le traite avec humanité. Et s'il était antichrétien, comme le prétendent les ennemis de notre race, avec qui les colons feraient-ils des affaires?

A-t-on vu une seule fois, en Egypte, le boycottage da comme ce européen, comme cela arrive quelquefois ailleurs ? Y a-t-il un seul musulman qui ait rompu ses relations avec un étranger on renvoyé un employé chrétien parce qu'il est d'une autre religion que la sienne? Ne voit-on pas au service de quelques riches musulmans plus d'employés chrétiens que de musulmans 1
Sir Edward Grey lui-même n'a-t-il pas senti que le mot fanatisme a choqué dans sa bouche la vérité et ne l'a-t-il pas remplacé dans son dernier discours par le terme agitation passa gère.

Et enfin comment se fait il que la confiance des financiers dans la tranquillité et les bonnes intentions du peuple égyptien eoit grande à tel point que malgré tout le bruit-fait autour du prétendu fanatisme, les prix des terrains et des titres aient haussé, alors que l'été est toujours en Egypte la saison du marasme pour les af faires ? N'est-ce pas là une preuve éclatante et décisive de l'inexistence du fanatisme en Bgypte ?

Dire que l'affaire de Denchawaï est une conséquence du prétenda fanatisme, c'est aller wimplement à l'encontre de la vérité et de l'humanité et se déclarer plas Anglais que les Anglais eux-mêmes. La lumière a été soffisam. ment faite sur cette triste affaire qui a indigné et révolté tout le monde civilisé.

Notre entente avec la Turquie a toujours été un des axiomes fondamentaux de notre politique. Le désaccord qui régnait entre lea cours de Yildiz et d'Abdine pendant le mouve ment arabiste a été la cause directe de notre malheur et de l'occupation anglaise. La Tarqaie étant la puissance suzeraine, son rôle et son action dans la question égyptienne doivent in- contestablement être considérables.

Je demande à ceux qui nient cette vérité de réfléchir un instant à ce qu'il adviendrait de l'Egypte si la Turquie conclaait un jour avec l'Angleterre un pacte semblable à l'accord anglo-français. Est-ce que notre pays ne per- drait pas alors tout ce qui reste de son autonomie ?

Dans ces conditions, comment s'étonner des liens qui attachent l'Egypte à la Turquie ? Cet attachement n'est-il pas en lui-même la mailleure protestation contre la continastion injustifiée de l'occupation? Et en quoi cette attitade peut-elle indiquer de notre part un renoncement à notre autonomie et à nos droits acceptés par la Turquie et sanotionnés par l'Europe?

Tous les diplomates français s'accordaient nous dire, quand ils étaient égyptophiles, que toute brouille avec la Turquie serait nuisible, sinon désastreuse, pour nos espéranges. Et ils se montraient inquiets toutes les fois que les rapports entre le sultan et le Khédive étaient un peu tendus. L'accord anglo-français ne peat pas détruire cette vérité. L'occupation est toujours là, et notre situation, au point de vae international, a même empiré par le chan... gement radical de la politique française.

Je demande à ceux qui ne se contentent pas de nous critiquer, mais qui vont jusqu'à nous calomnier, pourquoi ils troavent naturelles et logiques l'alliance de la France avec la Russie et son entente avec l'Angleterre, et pourquoi ils considèrent comme criminelle et antipatriotique notre entente avec la Tarquie.

D'ailleurs il faut mettre les points sur les i, car il n'est pas dans mes habitudes d'avancer des vérités mutilées. Notre sympathie pour la Tarquie et notre ardent désir de la voir en progrès, forte et sûre de son avenir, ne signifient point que nous oublions notre patrie. Notre amour pour l'Egypte passe avant tout. L'intérêt que vous prenez aux affaires de votre frère ou de votre parent ne peat jamais indiquer que vous sacrifier les vôtres !
Nous voulons l'Egypte aux Egyptiens. Je l'ai proclamé depuis douze ans bien haut, et je défie qui que ce soit de prouver le contraire par ane seale ligne, ane seale phrase on an seal mot de moi.
Le 15 août dernier, j'ai publié sur cette même question, dans le Daily Graphic, an article où j'ai écrit textuellement :

Des gens malintentionnés ou mal inform da sont allés jusqu'à prétendre. que les patriotes égyptiens qui travaillent à la libération de l'Egypte veulent tout simplement changer le jong anglais par un antre jong. C'est une calomnie qui a pour but de faire perdre aux Egyptiens la sympathie de tous les braves gens qui sont toujours pour les peuples dignes d'être indépendante et lattant pour cette indé- pendance.

Une explication est nécessaire. Nous voulons l'Egypte aux Egyptiens. Pas de joug étranger et pas de domination, étrangère. Ceux qui croient que le peuple égyptien en vent à l'Angleterre parce qu'elle est une puissance chré- tienne se trompent beaucoup. Le peuple égyptien en vent à l'occupant qui a eapé son indé pendance et effacé son nom comme "nation libre". S'il y avait à la place de l'Angleterre
